text:
Hi <@UVB9ZSPCH>. I was thinking of a way (if this doesnt already exist) to connected people to share resources. Since people will be impacted differently, we can facilitate connecting people in their community to other who can offer support or help.

In disaster response, mutual aid can be a good stop gap measure to address needs before they can be addressed by the government. This is done normally by tapping into existing networks like (neighborhood or city organizations, LOCAL religious orgs, informal medical or funerary groups, or leagues of sports teams, etc.)

For example, boston is doing this for students who were kicked out of their dorms. Linking the conversation with <@U0107JERE9L> below. <https://ethiopia-covid19.slack.com/archives/C010CNGTLKF/p1584644585011800>

text: <@U0106M26108> has joined the channel

Just some thoughts to spark ideation - so I'm not a local in Ethiopia nor am I an epidemiologist, so I don't want to prescribe solutions before better understanding what the actual needs are based on problems that've been identified from those more educated on what's going on. I'm planning to have a call with my cousin in Addis tomorrow so that he can give me a better picture of what things look like over there, but in the meantime I think we should really listen to those in the group who are local so we can optimize our efforts around initiatives that  1) have the greatest impact and 2) can be executed quickly. There are a few big-picture projects (reporting, etc) in the works, so I think this is a good place to discuss smaller picture projects targeting specific communities where we can provide immediate value.

From a PM perspective, this is how I look at things:
• The main goal of any initiative we take is to contain the spread of the virus. Everything else seems to fall under this...but correct me if I am wrong.
• Time is an essential variable here, so anything we do should be quickly shippable and have an immediate impact. We should take advantage of existing tools/communication channels when possible.
• Generally understood "best" ways to contain the virus are education (hygiene, communication of risks/symptoms, treatment, etc.), protection (staying home, covering cough, cleaning) and anything else in support of these - live streaming service for church or mobile payments, for instance 
• In general, the population we are building for has low access to tech/internet access, so we should keep this in mind with any considerations (i.e. perhaps some solutions require someone local to help facilitate, etc.). The elderly population is most vulnerable and has least access. Many have access to phones, but what about those who don't?  
• Some solutions may not require a technical element! Worth keeping in mind.
Hope that this starts some conversations around what we can begin to do in support.

There are a few big-picture projects (reporting, etc) in the works, so I think this is a good place to discuss smaller picture projects targeting specific communities where we can provide immediate value.

From a PM perspective, this is how I look at things:
The main goal of any initiative we take is to contain the spread of the virus. Everything else seems to fall under this...but correct me if I am wrong.
Time is an essential variable here, so anything we do should be quickly shippable and have an immediate impact. We should take advantage of existing tools/communication channels when possible.

Generally understood "best" ways to contain the virus are education (hygiene, communication of risks/symptoms, treatment, etc.), protection (staying home, covering cough, cleaning) and anything else in support of these - live streaming service for church or mobile payments, for instance

In general, the population we are building for has low access to tech/internet access, so we should keep this in mind with any considerations (i.e. perhaps some solutions require someone local to help facilitate, etc.). The elderly population is most vulnerable and has least access. Many have access to phones, but what about those who don't?
Some solutions may not require a technical element! Worth keeping in mind.
Hope that this starts some conversations around what we can begin to do in support.

text:
<@U0107A7161E>, you on it!

But yea, currently we don’t have this particular initiative in the works. We all got together originally over building software solutions, specifically catering to asks that we know DO NOT exist there.

Although I can’t say for sure, regarding it’s existence (maybe we can throw this in the <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TteOUncrCUHNY5xOK9V1l9jAZw4mcWeXQHDSLtCY0tE/edit?usp=sharing|doc here> & folks on the ground can share), otherwise, the common thread on this topic has been staying in & around software, since most of the people here are abroad & we need some sort of focus.

Throw it on the doc, though! Who knows? We might learn of an org or initiative doing the work that we can support!

text: Hello <@U010B7Q6XE0> - I am total agreement with the points you raised. I am focusing on the low/no tech solutions to some of the urgent /high impact things. Towards that end, I created folders and asked folks to generate ideas for 3 main ideas.

elements.text: Hello

- I am total agreement with the points you raised. I am focusing on the low/no tech solutions to some of the urgent /high impact things. Towards that end, I created folders and asked folks to generate ideas for 3 main ideas.

text:
Please add anything relevant to them at the corresponding google drive.
We are looking for actionable items so it can be used asap.
THANK YOU!

1) Low tech ideas to identify and track folks that are positive.
Spreadsheet - <https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1hFYPAI-i-HsgAlTYyTFrCcDASNLkSX7x?usp=sharing>

2. Creative campaigns - graphics & content around reducing stigma of being potentially infected

Spreadsheet -  <https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1hpqhvzBOx4o9w9676SGsT0c-4LJpP4n4?usp=sharing>


3. Ideas to help and protect the healthcare workers. Eg.. nurses in the US are creating DIY protective gear. Any information on details of material to do that or other ideas.

Spreadsheet -  <https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1lVap5ylRncPf_dZA0b5qT_qZiUj0ziD7?usp=sharing>
